trans-unit.source: Publishing events: event publishers
trans-unit.target: Publishing events: event publishers

trans-unit.source: Sending events to an Event Hub is accomplished either using HTTP POST or via an AMQP 1.0 connection.
trans-unit.target: Sending events to an Event Hub is accomplished either using HTTP POST or via an AMQP 1.0 connection.

trans-unit.source: The choice of which to use when depends on the specific scenario being addressed.
trans-unit.target: The choice of which to use when depends on the specific scenario being addressed.

trans-unit.source: AMQP 1.0 connections are metered as brokered connections in Service Bus and are more appropriate in scenarios with frequent higher message volumes and lower latency requirements as they provide a persistent messaging channel.
trans-unit.target: AMQP 1.0 connections are metered as brokered connections in Service Bus and are more appropriate in scenarios with frequent higher message volumes and lower latency requirements as they provide a persistent messaging channel.

trans-unit.source: Event Hubs are created and managed using the [NamespaceManager](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.namespacemanager.aspx) class.
trans-unit.target: Event Hubs are created and managed using the [NamespaceManager](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.namespacemanager.aspx) class.

trans-unit.source: Partition key
trans-unit.target: Partition key

trans-unit.source: The [EventData](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.aspx) class has a [PartitionKey](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.partitionkey.aspx) property that enables the sender to specify a value that is hashed to produce a partition assignment.
trans-unit.target: The [EventData](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.aspx) class has a [PartitionKey](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.partitionkey.aspx) property that enables the sender to specify a value that is hashed to produce a partition assignment.

trans-unit.source: Using a partition key ensures that all the events with the same key are sent to the same partition in the Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: Using a partition key ensures that all the events with the same key are sent to the same partition in the Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: Common partition keys include user session IDs and unique sender IDs.
trans-unit.target: Common partition keys include user session IDs and unique sender IDs.

trans-unit.source: The [PartitionKey](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.partitionkey.aspx) property is optional and can be provided when using the [Microsoft.ServiceBus.Messaging.EventHubClient.Send(Microsoft.ServiceBus.Messaging.EventData)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.aspx) or [Microsoft.ServiceBus.Messaging.EventHubClient.SendAsync(Microsoft.ServiceBus.Messaging.EventData)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.aspx) methods.
trans-unit.target: The [PartitionKey](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.partitionkey.aspx) property is optional and can be provided when using the [Microsoft.ServiceBus.Messaging.EventHubClient.Send(Microsoft.ServiceBus.Messaging.EventData)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.aspx) or [Microsoft.ServiceBus.Messaging.EventHubClient.SendAsync(Microsoft.ServiceBus.Messaging.EventData)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.aspx) methods.

trans-unit.source: If you do not provide a value for [PartitionKey](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.partitionkey.aspx), sent events are distributed to partitions using a round-robin model.
trans-unit.target: If you do not provide a value for [PartitionKey](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.partitionkey.aspx), sent events are distributed to partitions using a round-robin model.

trans-unit.source: Batch event send operations
trans-unit.target: Batch event send operations

trans-unit.source: Sending events in batches can dramatically increase throughput.
trans-unit.target: Sending events in batches can dramatically increase throughput.

trans-unit.source: The [SendBatch](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventhubclient.sendbatch.aspx) method takes an **IEnumerable** parameter of type [EventData](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.aspx) and sends the entire batch as an atomic operation to the Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: The [SendBatch](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventhubclient.sendbatch.aspx) method takes an **IEnumerable** parameter of type [EventData](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventdata.aspx) and sends the entire batch as an atomic operation to the Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: It is important to note that a single batch must not exceed the 256 KB limit of an event.
trans-unit.target: It is important to note that a single batch must not exceed the 256 KB limit of an event.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, each message in the batch uses the same publisher identity.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, each message in the batch uses the same publisher identity.

trans-unit.source: It is the responsibility of the sender to ensure that the batch does not exceed the maximum event size.
trans-unit.target: It is the responsibility of the sender to ensure that the batch does not exceed the maximum event size.

trans-unit.source: If it does, a client **Send** error is generated.
trans-unit.target: If it does, a client **Send** error is generated.

trans-unit.source: Send asynchronously and send at scale
trans-unit.target: Send asynchronously and send at scale

trans-unit.source: You can also send events to an Event Hub asynchronously.
trans-unit.target: You can also send events to an Event Hub asynchronously.

trans-unit.source: Sending asynchronously can increase the rate at which a client is able to send events.
trans-unit.target: Sending asynchronously can increase the rate at which a client is able to send events.

trans-unit.source: Both the [Send](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventhubclient.send.aspx) and [SendBatch](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventhubclient.sendbatch.aspx) methods are available in asynchronous versions that return a [Task](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.threading.tasks.task.aspx) object.
trans-unit.target: Both the [Send](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventhubclient.send.aspx) and [SendBatch](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventhubclient.sendbatch.aspx) methods are available in asynchronous versions that return a [Task](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.threading.tasks.task.aspx) object.

trans-unit.source: While this technique can increase throughput, it can also cause the client to continue to send events even while it is being throttled by the Event Hubs service and can result in the client experiencing failures or lost messages if not properly implemented.
trans-unit.target: While this technique can increase throughput, it can also cause the client to continue to send events even while it is being throttled by the Event Hubs service and can result in the client experiencing failures or lost messages if not properly implemented.

trans-unit.source: In addition, you can use the [RetryPolicy](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.cliententity.retrypolicy.aspx) property on the client to control client retry options.
trans-unit.target: In addition, you can use the [RetryPolicy](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.cliententity.retrypolicy.aspx) property on the client to control client retry options.

trans-unit.source: At this point, the host will attempt to acquire a lease on every partition in the Event Hub using a "greedy" algorithm.
trans-unit.target: At this point, the host will attempt to acquire a lease on every partition in the Event Hub using a "greedy" algorithm.

trans-unit.source: These leases will last for a given timeframe and must then be renewed.
trans-unit.target: These leases will last for a given timeframe and must then be renewed.

trans-unit.source: As new nodes, worker instances in this case, come online, they place lease reservations and over time the load shifts between nodes as each attempts to acquire more leases.

trans-unit.source: This dynamic capability enables CPU-based autoscaling to be applied to consumers for both scale-up and scale-down.
trans-unit.target: This dynamic capability enables CPU-based autoscaling to be applied to consumers for both scale-up and scale-down.

trans-unit.source: Because Event Hubs do not have a direct concept of message counts, average CPU utilization is often the best mechanism to measure back end or consumer scale.
trans-unit.target: Because Event Hubs do not have a direct concept of message counts, average CPU utilization is often the best mechanism to measure back end or consumer scale.

trans-unit.source: If publishers begin to publish more events than consumers can process, the CPU increase on consumers can be used to cause an auto-scale on worker instance count.
trans-unit.target: If publishers begin to publish more events than consumers can process, the CPU increase on consumers can be used to cause an auto-scale on worker instance count.

trans-unit.source: The [EventProcessorHost](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventprocessorhost.aspx) class also implements an Azure storage-based checkpointing mechanism.
trans-unit.target: The [EventProcessorHost](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventprocessorhost.aspx) class also implements an Azure storage-based checkpointing mechanism.

trans-unit.source: This mechanism stores the offset on a per partition basis, so that each consumer can determine what the last checkpoint from the previous consumer was.
trans-unit.target: This mechanism stores the offset on a per partition basis, so that each consumer can determine what the last checkpoint from the previous consumer was.

trans-unit.source: As partitions transition between nodes via leases, this is the synchronization mechanism that facilitates load shifting.

trans-unit.source: Publisher revocation
trans-unit.target: Publisher revocation

trans-unit.source: In addition to the advanced runtime features of [EventProcessorHost](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventprocessorhost.aspx), Event Hubs enables publisher revocation in order to block specific publishers from sending event to an Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: In addition to the advanced runtime features of [EventProcessorHost](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.servicebus.messaging.eventprocessorhost.aspx), Event Hubs enables publisher revocation in order to block specific publishers from sending event to an Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: These features are particularly useful if a publisher’s token has been compromised, or a software update is causing them to behave inappropriately.
trans-unit.target: These features are particularly useful if a publisher’s token has been compromised, or a software update is causing them to behave inappropriately.

trans-unit.source: In these situations, the publisher’s identity, which is part of their SAS token, can be blocked from publishing events.
trans-unit.target: In these situations, the publisher’s identity, which is part of their SAS token, can be blocked from publishing events.

trans-unit.source: For more information about publisher revocation and how to send to Event Hubs as a publisher, see the [Service Bus Event Hubs Large Scale Secure Publishing](https://code.msdn.microsoft.com/Service-Bus-Event-Hub-99ce67ab) sample.
trans-unit.target: For more information about publisher revocation and how to send to Event Hubs as a publisher, see the [Service Bus Event Hubs Large Scale Secure Publishing](https://code.msdn.microsoft.com/Service-Bus-Event-Hub-99ce67ab) sample.
